Fundamental Doctrine of the Bible

Spiritual growth starts when the Holy Spirit enters a believer’s heart. The Holy Spirit, who is your Comforter and Helper, lives in you. He teaches you the ways of God and reminds you of everything that Jesus taught. We need a firm foundation to stand against the deception of false doctrines. To be effective disciples, we also need to be confident in what we believe. The fundamental doctrines will help us to be mature followers of Jesus Christ.

All Scripture references in this article use the English Standard Version unless otherwise stated.


A transformation takes place when you prayerfully meditate on God’s righteous decrees. The Holy Spirit changes you from within, enabling you to live a victorious Christian life. It pleases the Father to restore His image in you and shine His light through you.

God intends to build up the body of Christ "until we all attain to the unity of the faith and of the knowledge of the Son of God, to mature manhood, to the measure of the stature of the fullness of Christ" (Eph 4:13).

We all therefore need a solid foundation as the basis of our growth. See how the book of Hebrews describe this foundation:

Now is the time for us to progress beyond the basic message of Christ and advance into perfection. The foundation has already been laid for us to build upon: turning away from our dead works to embrace faith in God, teaching about different baptisms, impartation by the laying on of hands, resurrection of the dead, and eternal judgment. So with God’s enablement we will move on to deeper truths. (Hebrews 6:1-3, TPT).

The purpose of this article is to explain the doctrines listed above. Having laid this foundation in our lives, we must grow toward spiritual maturity. I would strongly encourage all readers to study this material as a group. There is immeasurable value in the interactive participation of a group of Christians, sharing and learning from each other.

Faith in God Baptisms Laying on of hands Resurrection of the dead Eternal judgement

FAITH IN GOD

An indisputable part of our Christian foundation is FAITH IN GOD.

Abraham believed God, and it was counted to him as righteousness (James 2:23, ESV).

Faith implies a measure of personal trust in something beyond your natural reasoning and abilities. From childhood, we learn to become independent and take responsibility for our own safety, provision and well-being. We learn to rely on our own judgement. Trusting God for my salvation challenges the securities with which I surrounded my life. Consider the implications of this proverb:

Trust in the LORD with all your heart, and do not lean on your own understanding (Proverbs 3:5, ESV).

<<<<<<< HEAD

Faith is directly related to the proclamation of the word of Christ. =======

Faith is directly related to the proclamation of the word of Christ. It is the testimony of many Christians that their lives were deeply affected when they believed in God. When I encountered Christ as a young man at university, I experienced an instant transformation. I responded to the inner conviction of the Holy Spirit by praying the most important prayer I ever prayed, inviting Jesus into my life. After I prayed, I truly believed. I knew that I changed and that my life would never be the same again. >>>>>>> master

For “everyone who calls on the name of the Lord will be saved.” How then will they call on him in whom they have not believed? And how are they to believe in him of whom they have never heard? And how are they to hear without someone preaching? And how are they to preach unless they are sent? As it is written, “How beautiful are the feet of those who preach the good news!” But they have not all obeyed the gospel. For Isaiah says, “Lord, who has believed what he has heard from us?” So faith comes from hearing, and hearing through the word of Christ (Romans 10:13-17).

We exercise faith to trust God for our salvation. Then, throughout our lives, faith is an essential part of our living and breathing as God's children. Whenever we pray, we trust God that He will reward those who earnestly seek him wholeheartedly.

And without faith it is impossible to please him, for whoever would draw near to God must believe that he exists and that he rewards those who seek him (Hebrews 11:6)

BAPTISMS

1. The baptism of John the Baptist

<<<<<<< HEAD

Now John wore a garment of camel's hair and a leather belt around his waist, and his food was locusts and wild honey. Then Jerusalem and all Judea and all the region about the Jordan were going out to him, and they were baptized by him in the river Jordan, confessing their sins (Matthew 3:4-6, ESV)

=======

Image by Ahstubbs from Pixabay

The book of Matthew describes the unique ministry of John the Baptist, the one, anointed by God to prepare the way of the Messiah.

In those days John the Baptist came preaching in the wilderness of Judea, “Repent, for the kingdom of heaven is at hand.” For this is he who was spoken of by the prophet Isaiah when he said, “The voice of one crying in the wilderness: ‘Prepare the way of the Lord; make his paths straight.’”

Now John wore a garment of camel's hair and a leather belt around his waist, and is food was locusts and wild honey. Then Jerusalem and all Judea and all the region about the Jordan were going out to him, and they were baptized by him in the river Jordan, confessing their sins (Matthew 3:1-6, ESV)

>>>>>>> master

The baptism of John was a prophetic event, proclaiming the arrival of someone much greater than he. He warned the people of Israel to repent of their sins and turn away from evil so that their sins may be forgiven. When some thought that John could be the Christ, he answered them:

I baptize you with water, but he who is mightier than I is coming, the strap of whose sandals I am not worthy to untie. He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and fire (Luke 3:16, ESV).

His ministry reached its climax when Jesus came and requested that He also be baptised.

Now when all the people were baptized, and when Jesus also had been baptized and was praying, the heavens were opened, and the Holy Spirit descended on him in bodily form, like a dove; and a voice came from heaven, “You are my beloved Son; with you I am well pleased (Luke 3:21-22, ESV).

2. Water baptism - the sign of accepting the message of Jesus Christ

The apostle Peter concluded his sermon on the day of Pentecost with these words:

"...Let all the house of Israel therefore know for certain that God has made him both Lord and Christ, this Jesus whom you crucified.” Now when they heard this they were cut to the heart, and said to Peter and the rest of the apostles, “Brothers, what shall we do?” And Peter said to them, “Repent and be baptized every one of you in the name of Jesus Christ for the forgiveness of your sins, and you will receive the gift of the Holy Spirit. For the promise is for you and for your children and for all who are far off, everyone whom the Lord our God calls to himself.” And with many other words he bore witness and continued to exhort them, saying, “Save yourselves from this crooked generation.” So those who received his word were baptized, and there were added that day about three thousand souls. (Acts 2:36-41)

It was the departing instruction of Jesus Christ to His eleven disciples to go and make disciples of all nations. The baptism of believers is accompanied by the teaching of the message of Jesus Christ. Those who accept His message must be baptised and must be obedient.

And Jesus came and said to them, “All authority in heaven and on earth has been given to me. Go therefore and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit, teaching them to observe all that I have commanded you. And behold, I am with you always, to the end of the age” (Matthew 28:18-20).

Baptism, for believers, is also a symbol of identifying with the death and resurrection of Jesus Christ.

Do you not know that all of us who have been baptized into Christ Jesus were baptized into his death? We were buried therefore with him by baptism into death, in order that, just as Christ was raised from the dead by the glory of the Father, we too might walk in newness of life (Romans 6:3-4)

3. Baptism of the Holy Spirit

Recall what John the Baptist told the people about the One who would come after him: He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and fire. John the Baptist baptised with water but Jesus baptised with the Holy Spirit and fire. Keep in mind that the disciples of Jesus had already been born again. We read in John 20:22 how Jesus breathed on them, saying "Receive the Holy Spirit". Pentecost happened afterwards. Luke wrote about Pentecost as the promise of the Father:

<<<<<<< HEAD =======

Image by michel kwan from Pixabay

>>>>>>> master

And while staying with them he ordered them not to depart from Jerusalem, but to wait for the promise of the Father, which, he said, “you heard from me; for John baptized with water, but you will be baptized with the Holy Spirit not many days from now” (Acts 1:4,5).

In the description of what happened on the day of Pentecost, we read again about the fire that was prophesied. This kind of baptism was initiated by the Holy Spirit and it's purpose was to enable the disciples to boldly proclaim the good news about Jesus Christ. Up to this stage, the Jews were not concerned about the salvation of the nations but this was about to change. God elected Israel for a purpose, much greater than the preservation of their own identity. Christ, the Messiah, came to save the whole world from their sins.

When the day of Pentecost arrived, they were all together in one place. And suddenly there came from heaven a sound like a mighty rushing wind, and it filled the entire house where they were sitting. And divided tongues as of fire appeared to them and rested on each one of them. And they were all filled with the Holy Spirit and began to speak in other tongues as the Spirit gave them utterance. (Acts 2:1-4)

After the day of Pentecost, the disciples continued to teach the Jews that the same Jesus they had crucified came to fulfil the prophecies in the Scripture about the promised Messiah. In Acts 4 we continue to read how Peter and John boldly proclaimed the message of the resurrection of the dead. Their preaching was followed by prayer and everyone that was there continued to witness the work of the Holy Spirit.

And when they had prayed, the place in which they were gathered together was shaken, and they were all filled with the Holy Spirit and continued to speak the word of God with boldness (Acts 4:31).

When Paul arrived at Ephesus, he came across disciples who were baptised by John the Baptist. These disciples were not yet taught about the Holy Spirit. Paul then explained to them that the baptism of John actually pointed to Jesus who baptised with the Holy Spirit. They gladly received Paul's message!

On hearing this, they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus. And when Paul had laid his hands on them, the Holy Spirit came on them, and they began speaking in tongues and prophesying (Acts 19:5-6).

Recommended for discussion:

  • What was significant about the symbol of fire?
  • How does the Holy Spirit continue to transform the lives of people today?

THE LAYING ON OF HANDS

Jesus laid his hands on sick people and by the authority of His Word they were healed. Through this ministry, Jesus demonstrated his love and compassion to the world. People learned that God really cared.

<<<<<<< HEAD =======

Image by 95C from Pixabay

>>>>>>> master

Now when the sun was setting, all those who had any who were sick with various diseases brought them to him, and he laid his hands on every one of them and healed them (Luke 4:40).

Then came one of the rulers of the synagogue, Jairus by name, and seeing him, he fell at his feet and implored him earnestly, saying, “My little daughter is at the point of death. Come and lay your hands on her, so that she may be made well and live. And he went with him” (Mark 5:22-24a).

When Jesus saw her, he called her over and said to her, “Woman, you are freed from your disability.” And he laid his hands on her, and immediately she was made straight, and she glorified God (Luke 13:12,13).

The caring ministry of Jesus was continued by his disciples. The Holy Spirit living in the disciples enabled them to show everyone that God was alive and still desired to transform human lives. The disciples laid their hands on people so that they would receive the Holy Spirit. In the church, today, the <<<<<<< HEAD laying on of hands imparts a gift of God. This gift could take the form of healing, or the infilling of the Holy Spirit. The practice of laying on of hands was also used to commission people for service or ministry.

Do not neglect the gift you have, which was given you by prophecy when the council of elders laid their hands on you (1 Timothy 4:14)

As I remember your tears, I long to see you, that I may be filled with joy. THE RESURRECTION OF THE DEAD

<<<<<<< HEAD =======

The resurrection of Jesus from the dead and the subsequent pouring out of the Holy Spirit was the birth of the church. However, these events also distinguished Christianity from all known religions on earth. It was not just another attempt of human kind to reach out to God in order to gain some kind of acceptance. No human being was involved in the resurrection, rather, it was the loving and gracious initiative of God to reach out to all peoples. All people were completely seperated from God because of sin and everyone desperately needed God's intervention to give hope to a dying world. The resurrection of Jesus was also the foundation of a new relationship between God and man. Christianity is not a religion, but a relationship that would last until eternity!

Every part of the human life of Jesus was prophesied thousands of years before it happened, and the resurrection of Jesus was no acception. The way in which it happened was also extra-ordinary. The book of Matthew relates how an angel rolled away the stone at the entrance of the grave:

And behold, there was a great earthquake, for an angel of the Lord descended from heaven and came and rolled back the stone and sat on it. His appearance was like lightning, and his clothing white as snow. And for fear of him the guards trembled and became like dead men. But the angel said to the women, “Do not be afraid, for I know that you seek Jesus who was crucified. He is not here, for he has risen, as he said (Matthew 28:2-6a).

In 1 Corinthians 15, the apostle Paul reflects on the mission of Jesus Christ, that he died for our sins but rose again on the third day. He then appeard to his disciples and also to many others, including "more than five hundred brothers at one time". The resurrection of Christ is also our hope and first evidence of eternal life with Him.

But in fact Christ has been raised from the dead, the firstfruits of those who have fallen asleep. For as by a man came death, by a man has come also the resurrection of the dead. For as in Adam all die, so also in Christ shall all be made alive. But each in his own order: Christ the firstfruits, then at his coming those who belong to Christ (1 Corinthians 15:20-23).

The resurrection of the believers is followed by the glorious announcement of a new kingdom: "Then comes the end, when he delivers the kingdom to God the Father after destroying every rule and every authority and power. For he must reign until he has put all his enemies under his feet. The last enemy to be destroyed is death"() (1 Cor 15:24-26).

In his letter to the Philippians, the apostle Paul says that he found "the righteousness from God that depends on faith". The resurrection power of God also has a significance for our spiritual life and indicates the victory that Christ secured for us.

that I may know him and the power of his resurrection, and may share his sufferings, becoming like him in his death, that by any means possible I may attain the resurrection from the dead" (Philippians 3:10-11)
